description: Emphasizes texture and tone over traditional musical structure, aimed at evoking a particular atmosphere or mood.

subgenres.name: Ambient Americana
subgenres.description: Ambient music made using traditional Americana and Country instrumentation.

subgenres.name: Ambient Noise Wall
subgenres.description: Combines the static approach of Harsh Noise Wall with textures leaning towards Ambient music.

subgenres.name: Dark Ambient
subgenres.description: Emphasizes an ominous, gloomy, and dissonant atmosphere.

subgenres.name: Black Ambient
subgenres.description: Incorporates elements such as guitars, synthesizers, harsh or whispered vocals, raw production, or other elements associated with Black Metal and Dungeon Synth.

subgenres.name: Ritual Ambient
subgenres.description: Dark, deep, disturbing, ritualistic, and occult atmosphere.

subgenres.name: Space Ambient
subgenres.description: Flowing and relaxing synthesizer-based music derived from Progressive Electronic, often oriented around imagery of outer space.

subgenres.name: Tribal Ambient
subgenres.description: Combines the theory and atmosphere of Ambient with traditional instruments and sounds from around the globe.

description: Originated toward the end of the 19th century in African American communities in the United States, particularly the Deep South; drew on traditional Spirituals and Work Songs; highly influential to the whole of Western popular music.

subgenres.name: Acoustic Blues
subgenres.description: Developed out of Work Songs and Spirituals to become the most prominent early form of Blues.

subgenres.name: Acoustic Chicago Blues
subgenres.description: Unplugged Blues made in the Chicago region, primarily during the 1930s and 1940s.

subgenres.name: Acoustic Texas Blues
subgenres.description: Laid-back swing rhythms and guitar ornamentation, including solos.

subgenres.name: Jug Band
subgenres.description: Usually features a jug as the bass instrument as well as other homemade (or easily affordable) instruments, such as kazoos and washboards.

subgenres.name: Piedmont Blues
subgenres.description: Developed in the early 20th century in the southern Appalachian foothills and characterized by a syncopated but melodic Ragtime-based finger-picking acoustic guitar style.

subgenres.name: Boogie Woogie
subgenres.description: Early, uptempo Blues featuring the piano as the main instrument, with soloing and improvisation played over the top of a repetitive eight note baseline.

subgenres.name: Country Blues
subgenres.description: Various styles of Blues originating in the rural US South, typically relying on expressive vocal delivery and featuring simple, usually acoustic instrumentation.

subgenres.name: Delta Blues
subgenres.description: One of the earliest forms of Blues, named for the Mississippi Delta region of the United States where it developed, with a highly rhythmic style and a typical 12-bar structure.

subgenres.name: Hill Country Blues
subgenres.description: Emphasizes a steady hypnotic groove, sparse percussive and highly energetic guitar riffs, and often features meandering structures with unconventional and usually fewer chord changes compared to Delta Blues.

subgenres.name: Electric Blues
subgenres.description: Major development in sound and reach of Blues when it became possible to amplify the instruments of small combos.

subgenres.name: British Blues
subgenres.description: Heavily influenced by the burgeoning United States Blues scene, particularly Chicago Blues.

subgenres.name: Chicago Blues
subgenres.description: Heavily inspired by old-time rural blues, transferring it into a small band setup, while maintaining the rough and gritty edges of its ancestry.

subgenres.name: Electric Texas Blues
subgenres.description: Originating in (but not limited to) Texas; includes Jazz influences like Swing rhythms and sometimes the addition of a horn section.

subgenres.name: Swamp Blues
subgenres.description: Originated in Baton Rouge, Louisiana in the 1950s, with a laid-back and relaxed sound that takes influence from Zydeco and Cajun Music.

subgenres.name: Fife and Drum Blues
subgenres.description: Rooted in martial Fife and Drum Corps music, originated among Afro-American communities in Mississippi.

subgenres.name: Jump Blues
subgenres.description: Emerged in the late 1930s with influence from jazz styles such as Swing and Big Band, featuring fast tempos and raucous performances.

subgenres.name: New Orleans Blues
subgenres.description: Diverse scene in New Orleans since the beginning of the 20th century, commonly associated with a sound led by rollicking pianos with syncopated beats and backed by horns.

subgenres.name: Piano Blues
subgenres.description: Played either solo or with the piano as the lead instrument of a small combo performing slow or mid-tempo blues ballads, as opposed to the commonly fast-paced Boogie Woogie.

subgenres.name: Soul Blues
subgenres.description: Shares similarities with Soul and incorporates the eponymous soulful inflections of Gospel, Jump Blues and soul into the vocals.

subgenres.name: Vaudeville Blues
subgenres.description: Vaudeville incorporating heavy Blues elements.

description: Part of a broad generalization about the structure and function of music throughout history across the globe, describing traditions distinct from Traditional Folk Music and popular music.

subgenres.name: Arabic Classical Music
subgenres.description: Arabic Classical Music tradition, whose guidelines for modulation, rhythm, and tuning were set down in treatises in the 8th and 9th centuries, based around Islamic Modal Music.

subgenres.name: Andalusian Classical Music
subgenres.description: Arabic Classical Music tradition that had its beginnings in Al-Andalus, the medieval Islamic Iberian peninsula, which later spread and developed in the Maghreb.

subgenres.name: Iraqi Maqam
subgenres.description: Highly structured but semi-improvised and rhythmically complex compositions built around set structures which consist of specific maqam modes.

subgenres.name: Sawt
subgenres.description: Poetic vocal form with complex rhythms, emotive singing, and distinctive lute-backed melodies commonly found in the Gulf region and based on a maqam system.

subgenres.name: Azerbaijani Mugham
subgenres.description: Highly improvisational form of modal music characterized by the singing style and the themes of Azerbaijan's history.

subgenres.name: Arabic Classical Music
subgenres.description: Arabic Classical Music tradition, whose guidelines for modulation, rhythm, and tuning were set down in treatises in the 8th and 9th centuries, based around Islamic Modal Music.

subgenres.name: Chinese Classical Music
subgenres.description: Classical Music of China, encompassing royal court music as well as the Chinese Opera musical theatre traditions.

subgenres.name: Opera
subgenres.description: European tradition which combines drama and distinctive vocal style in the context of Western Classical Music, usually performed as a theatrical work on stage.

subgenres.name: Opera seria
subgenres.description: Italian Opera popular among European nobility and royalty throughout most of the 18th century, typified by its exaggerated dramatic flair and interspersed with dry recitative.

subgenres.name: Operetta
subgenres.description: Light opera interspersed with spoken dialogues, being usually satirical and/or humorous in nature and centered around romantic plots and dancing scenes.

subgenres.name: Buganda Royal Court Music
subgenres.description: Highest traditional and refined musical forms of Buganda, reserved for the Kabaka (the king of Buganda).

subgenres.name: East Asian Classical Music
subgenres.description: Covers all the forms of pan-East Asian Classical Music sharing origins in Chinese Classical Music.

subgenres.name: Chinese Classical Music
subgenres.description: Classical Music of China, encompassing royal court music as well as the Chinese Opera musical theatre traditions.

subgenres.name: Baihua xiyue
subgenres.description: Mainly performed for funeral ceremonies of the Naxi ethnic group in the Yunnan province in China.

subgenres.name: Chinese Opera
subgenres.description: Traditional Chinese theatre, existing in several regional variations, combining traditional instruments and vocals along with other art forms like Poetry, dance, acrobatics, and martial arts.

subgenres.name: Cantonese Opera
subgenres.description: Chinese Opera that are sung in Cantonese.

subgenres.name: Japanese Classical Music
subgenres.description: Classical music of Japan.

subgenres.name: Gagaku
subgenres.description: One of the oldest forms of Japanese Classical Music, based on the pentatonic Yo scale, characterized by an elegant sound that is typically solemn, slow-paced, and resonant.

subgenres.name: Shomyo
subgenres.description: Japanese Buddhist chant that utilizes the yo scale.

subgenres.name: Vietnamese Classical Music
subgenres.description: Traditional court music of Vietnam, often performed by a twelve-instrument ensemble (for Dai Nhac music) or a fourteen-instrument ensemble (for Nha Nhac music).

subgenres.name: Ca tru
subgenres.description: Sung poetry from northern Vietnam, performed by a female vocalist to the accompaniment of a three-stringed lute and percussion.

subgenres.name: Korean Classical Music
subgenres.description: Classical Music of Korea.

subgenres.name: Aak
subgenres.description: Korean Classical Music that dates back to the early 12th century.

subgenres.name: Persian Classical Music
subgenres.description: Traditional art music of the Persian civilization.

subgenres.name: South Asian Classical Music
subgenres.description: Meta-genre that covers the diverse forms of Classical Music from South Asia.

subgenres.name: Carnatic Classical Music
subgenres.description: Culture shared by the Dravidian cultures in South India separate from regional folk genres.

subgenres.name: Southeast Asian Classical Music
subgenres.description: Formal music developed in Southeast Asian countries.

subgenres.name: Gamelan
subgenres.description: Originated in the island of Java, played by an ensemble typically consisting of metallophones and gongs, sometimes augmented with drums, flutes, and human voices.

subgenres.name: Western Classical Music
subgenres.description: Broad range of art music associated with the aristocracy that originated in Europe around 500 AD.

subgenres.name: Baroque Music
subgenres.description: Style of Western art music composed from approximately 1600 to 1750, embracing a grand and ornate approach.

subgenres.name: Renaissance Music
subgenres.description: Encompasses Western Classical Music from the 15th to 16th centuries.

subgenres.name: Madrigal
subgenres.description: Secular polyphonic music based around poetry and generally performed by unaccompanied vocal ensembles.

subgenres.name: Medieval Music
subgenres.description: Includes a variety of Western music styles from the 5th to the 15th century.

subgenres.name: Gregorian Chant
subgenres.description: Liturgical, monophonic chant that accompanied Mass and other rituals in Western Christianity.

subgenres.name: Modern Classical
subgenres.description: Multitude of different compositional approaches beginning in the 20th century that deviate significantly from the previously-held tenets.

subgenres.name: Expressionism
subgenres.description: Originating between the abandonment of tonality at the conclusion of the period of Romanticism and the creation of twelve-tone composition.

description: Rooted in Disco and developed largely within Electronic Dance Music; emphasizes rhythm and is generally produced for play by DJs at clubs, parties, or festivals.

subgenres.name: Alternative Dance
subgenres.description: Incorporates rhythms and synthesizers from Electronic Dance Music within the context of Alternative Rock and related styles; predominantly popular in the 1990s.

subgenres.name: Grebo
subgenres.description: Short-lived English subculture and associated music; raw, futuristic, sample-heavy form of Alternative Dance with a grungy guitar sound.

subgenres.name: New Rave
subgenres.description: High energy mid-2000s form of Alternative Dance that combines Dance-Punk with elements of Electronic Dance Music styles like Electroclash and Electro House.

subgenres.name: Dance-Pop
subgenres.description: Simple, yet catchy melodies and throbbing beats inspired initially by Disco and later various House styles.

subgenres.name: Bubblegum Dance
subgenres.description: Playful, childlike style with a Bubblegum-like atmosphere that often incorporates high-pitched, light-hearted, and usually female-fronted vocals.

subgenres.name: Disco polo
subgenres.description: Polish Dance-Pop, originally established from contemporary wedding / feast songs and Italo-Disco.

subgenres.name: Freestyle
subgenres.description: Electro-influenced; developed in Latino communities in New York and Miami in the 1980s, especially dominated by Latin Freestyle and its Latin influences.

subgenres.name: Latin Freestyle
subgenres.description: Displays a heavy influence of Hispanic American Music alongside the Disco, Hip Hop, and Electro influences of Freestyle.

subgenres.name: Funk melody
subgenres.description: Light and melodic take on Funk brasileiro, developed alongside Funk carioca.

subgenres.name: Romanian Popcorn
subgenres.description: Emerged in the second half of the 2000s in Romania, often featuring brass melodies and 'staccato' pluck grooves.

subgenres.name: Tecnorumba
subgenres.description: Blend of the themes and singing style of Rumba flamenca with the most commercial forms of House, Techno, and Makina.

subgenres.name: Township Bubblegum
subgenres.description: Synth-heavy Dance-Pop style popular in the South African townships in the 1980s and early 1990s.

subgenres.name: Disco
subgenres.description: Combines the lush orchestration of Philly Soul and bass grooves of Funk with a four-on-the-floor rhythm.

subgenres.name: Boogie
subgenres.description: Continuation of the Disco sound with increased influence from Funk, Synth Funk, and R&B and a slower tempo, often featuring drum machines and filter modulated synthesizers.

subgenres.name: Electro-Disco
subgenres.description: Disco instrumentation is largely - if not entirely - replaced by synthesizers and augmented with futuristic elements such as the vocoder.

subgenres.name: Hi-NRG
subgenres.description: Emerged in the late 1970s and quickly became the most popular form of Electronic Dance Music in the LGBT club scenes of San Francisco and New York, characterized by its uptempo, high-energy sound.

subgenres.name: Italo-Disco
subgenres.description: Produced primarily in Italy and is characterized by the use of synthesizers, drum machines, and sometimes vocoders to create a mechanical, Electronic version of Disco with futuristic atmosphere.

subgenres.name: Space Disco
subgenres.description: Emerged in Europe in the mid-to-late 1970s, characterized by layers of oscillating synth, space-oriented sound effects, and a futuristic sound inspired by contemporary sci-fi media.

subgenres.name: Euro-Disco
subgenres.description: European style that moved away from the genre's Rhythm & Blues and Soul roots, speeding up the tempo and adding Electronic instruments like synthesizers and drum machines as a backing for more melodic Europop-influenced vocals.

subgenres.name: Latin Disco
subgenres.description: Disco that incorporates elements from Hispanic American Music styles.

subgenres.name: Mutant Disco
subgenres.description: Danceable basslines, syncopated grooves, and angular guitar riffs, characterized by a spirit of experimentation and integration of disparate sounds.

subgenres.name: Nu-Disco
subgenres.description: 21st-century trend mixing modern, polished Electronic production with the aesthetics, structures, and lively, organic beats of 1970s and 1980s Disco.

subgenres.name: Electronic Dance Music
subgenres.description: Broad category for subgenres mainly derived from Disco, featuring Electronic sounds, synthesizers, drum machines and varying BPM ranges.

subgenres.name: Breakbeat
subgenres.description: An umbrella of affiliated Electronic Dance Music styles broadly characterized by prominent syncopated drum patterns (called breakbeats) that emerged from Breakbeat Hardcore's initial influence, not including styles directly related to Drum and Bass and Jungle.

subgenres.name: Acid Breaks
subgenres.description: Incorporates prominent 'squelching', resonant low pass filter sounds typical to Acid House, and often other 'trippy' effects into intense, syncopated, broken rhythms in the tempos of 110-150 BPM.

subgenres.name: Baltimore Club
subgenres.description: Drew on the 'booty bass' syncopation of Miami Bass, combined with Breakbeat rhythms around 130 BPM and chopped up vocal samples as found in Ghetto House.

subgenres.name: Big Beat
subgenres.description: Popular in Britain during the late 1990s, driven by edited breakbeats and prominent basslines.

subgenres.name: Breakbeat Hardcore
subgenres.description: Originated from the combination of sampled breakbeats and energetic rhythms with the 'rave' influences set by early-1990s Techno and Acid House, including upbeat 'stab' riffing and sample-based production.

subgenres.name: Breakbeat Kota
subgenres.description: Indonesian style that slows down the syncopated rhythms of Funkot to moderate tempos around 130 BPM.

subgenres.name: Florida Breaks
subgenres.description: Developed during the mid-1990s, combining major influences of Hip Hop derivatives such as Miami Bass and Electro along with elements of 1990s Electronic Dance Music genres like House or Techno.

subgenres.name: Nu Skool Breaks
subgenres.description: Developed in the late 1990s and early 2000s; combines elements from Drum and Bass, UK Garage, and Techno with breakbeat.

subgenres.name: Progressive Breaks
subgenres.description: Derivative of Progressive House that incorporates its lush, melodic synth leads and atmospheres into Breakbeat's syncopated and broken rhythms.

subgenres.name: Psybreaks
subgenres.description: Uses Psytrance-derived sound design, such as squelchy sounds and psychedelic effects.

subgenres.name: West Coast Breaks
subgenres.description: Combines the earlier breakbeats of Hip Hop and early Breakbeat or even Miami Bass, with various 1990s Electronic Dance Music genres like Trance and Techno.

subgenres.name: Drum and Bass
subgenres.description: Typified by fast, syncopated breakbeat patterns (often sampled or programmed) with prominent basslines, commonly within the 160-180 BPM range.

subgenres.name: Atmospheric Drum and Bass
subgenres.description: Prominent in the mid-1990s, distinguished by its use of faster, de-emphasized breakbeats and a greater focus on more melodic elements like slow, warm basslines and atmospheric melodies inspired by Ambient and Ambient House.

subgenres.name: Dancefloor Drum and Bass
subgenres.description: Emerged in the late 2000s and early 2010s as a form of simpler, lighter and more melodic Drum and Bass in comparison to many of the drum and bass genres which preceded it.

subgenres.name: Darkstep
subgenres.description: Hard, uptempo and uses heavy breakbeats, Post-Industrial-influenced sound design, and horror movie samples to create a sinister, claustrophobic atmosphere.

subgenres.name: Drumfunk
subgenres.description: Focuses on complex drum beats made to emulate live recordings.

subgenres.name: Drumstep
subgenres.description: Dancefloor-friendly, loud, and heavy combination of the drum programming of Jump-Up with the half-time tempo and midrange LFO wobble of Brostep.

subgenres.name: Dubwise Drum and Bass
subgenres.description: Implementing Reggae and Dub influences, usually vocal dubs, delay effects, and reggae instrumentation, with the clean production and rhythms of post-2000s styles.

subgenres.name: Footwork Jungle
subgenres.description: Combining Footwork's archetypal percussion, skittering drum fills, handclaps, and syncopated rhythms, with Drum and Bass drum programming and breakbeats, merging the two into unconventional, frantic drumming and dense, off-kilter rhythms.

subgenres.name: Halftime
subgenres.description: Offshoot of Drum and Bass (mainly Neurofunk) characterized by off-kilter rhythms playing at around 80-85 BPM (half of normal DnB pace), influenced by Dubstep, Wonky, Trap [EDM], and Hip Hop.

subgenres.name: Hardstep
subgenres.description: Very compressed and sparse drumming, extensive use of kick drums and gritty, minimalistic production style with emphasis on simple, deep, modulated bass patterns.

subgenres.name: Jazzstep
subgenres.description: Combines the rhythm and speed of Drum and Bass with the melodies, composition, and instrumentation of Jazz.

subgenres.name: Jump-Up
subgenres.description: Emerged in the mid-1990s, characterized by loud 'wobbling' basslines, simpler drum loops, and a light-hearted and warm sound.

subgenres.name: Jungle
subgenres.description: Developed in the early 1990s from Breakbeat Hardcore, featuring rapid, chaotic-sounding breakbeats and strong basslines; known as the forerunner of most Drum and Bass styles.

subgenres.name: Liquid Drum and Bass
subgenres.description: Atmospheric and melodic genre that developed in the early 2000s; utilizes polished and smooth production, simpler structures, and originally sampled Funk and Soul.

subgenres.name: Minimal Drum and Bass
subgenres.description: Drum and Bass which strips down the sound as far as it can go without wholly ceasing to be drum and bass.

subgenres.name: Neurofunk
subgenres.description: Focuses on technical songwriting with warped, complex bass sounds, distorted and modulated synths (often with repeated stabs over the basslines), and dark but clean production.

subgenres.name: Techstep
subgenres.description: Futuristic, dark, and gritty sound; quantized and compressed drum breaks, distorted bass lines, and a focus on a sci-fi atmosphere and sampling sources.

subgenres.name: Trancestep
subgenres.description: Combination of Trance melodies and structure with the breakbeats, fast tempos, and rolling basslines of Drum and Bass.

subgenres.name: Dubstep
subgenres.description: Characterized by half-time syncopated and sparse beats set around 140 BPM with heavy sub-basses; emerged in South London in the early 2000s.

subgenres.name: Brostep
subgenres.description: Offshoot of Dubstep which replaces its sub-bass-oriented sound with an emphasis on catchy or aggressive mid-range melodies.

subgenres.name: Briddim
subgenres.description: Combining the kick-clap rhythms and syncopation of Riddim with Brostep sound design.

subgenres.name: Colour Bass
subgenres.description: Combines aggressive wobbling basses with the euphoric drops of Melodic Dubstep and Future Bass.

subgenres.name: Deathstep
subgenres.description: Darker, heavier form of Brostep that uses 'machine gun' basses, atonal synths, and elements from genres like Death Metal and Metalcore.

subgenres.name: Drumstep
subgenres.description: Dancefloor-friendly, loud, and heavy combination of the drum programming of Jump-Up with the half-time tempo and midrange LFO wobble of Brostep.

subgenres.name: Tearout [Brostep]
subgenres.description: Heavy and distorted, closely affiliated with Deathstep and other styles of Brostep.

subgenres.name: Chillstep
subgenres.description: Relaxed Dubstep influenced by Downtempo and Ambient.

subgenres.name: Dungeon Sound
subgenres.description: Commonly features dark textures, spatial production, and midrange basses.

subgenres.name: Melodic Dubstep
subgenres.description: Melodious, tuneful drops, rich, lush synth leads, powerful stretched chords, and light and harmonious sound design.

subgenres.name: Purple Sound
subgenres.description: Emerged in the late 2000s out of the Dubstep scene of the time, incorporating synth leads and basslines inspired by 1980s Synth Funk and 1990s G-Funk, and Video Game Music, into a rhythmic palette mostly derived from dubstep and Grime.

subgenres.name: Riddim
subgenres.description: Heavy use of repetition and wet, metallic sound design.

subgenres.name: Tearout
subgenres.description: Emerged in the late 2000s, characterized by a gritty, aggressive sound and closely affiliated with early, deep Dubstep.

subgenres.name: East Coast Club
subgenres.description: Group of club styles from the US East Coast that combines Miami Bass rhythms with influence from Breakbeat and Ghetto House.

subgenres.name: Baltimore Club
subgenres.description: Drew on the 'booty bass' syncopation of Miami Bass, combined with Breakbeat rhythms around 130 BPM and chopped up vocal samples as found in Ghetto House.

subgenres.name: Jersey Club
subgenres.description: Emerged in Newark in the late 2000s; features fast tempos, hard kicks, and less prominent breakbeats.

subgenres.name: Philly Club
subgenres.description: Builds on Baltimore Club with a faster tempo and sometimes influences from more modern genres like Trap [EDM].

subgenres.name: EBM
subgenres.description: Melodic and beat-driven Electronic Dance Music take on Post-Industrial that developed in the 1980s.

subgenres.name: Dark Electro
subgenres.description: Emerged in the early 1990s in Europe, combining EBM beats with the abrasiveness of old school Industrial but with a greater focus on a horror-inspired atmosphere and harsh, distorted vocals.

subgenres.name: Futurepop
subgenres.description: Derivative of EBM, retaining its apocalyptic worldview but incorporating heavy influence from the melodic style of Synthpop.

subgenres.name: New Beat
subgenres.description: Underground dance music which originated in Belgium around 1987, tending to resemble slower, harder EBM.

subgenres.name: Electro
subgenres.description: Syncopated rhythms programmed on the Roland TR-808 drum machine, often resembling Funk breaks, along with simple funky basslines.

subgenres.name: Skweee
subgenres.description: Originated among Nordic artists in the mid-2000s, inspired by elements of Synth Funk, Hip Hop, and IDM.

subgenres.name: Electroclash
subgenres.description: Draws from 1980s styles such as Electro, New Wave, and Electro-Disco combined with Techno, resulting in minimal, throbbing beats and basslines, buzzing synthesizer parts, vocoders and often monotone, half-spoken, half-sung vocals.

subgenres.name: Electro-Disco
subgenres.description: Disco instrumentation is largely - if not entirely - replaced by synthesizers and augmented with futuristic elements such as the vocoder.

subgenres.name: Electro Latino
subgenres.description: Mixes elements of Merengue and Reggaetón with polished production from mainstream House subgenres; often shares traits with Latin Pop, having anthemic melodies and verse-chorus structures.

subgenres.name: Electro Swing
subgenres.description: Upbeat, energetic style that splices Swing with Electronic Dance Music, looking to recapture the atmosphere of late 1920s to mid-1940s Jazz within a more updated club-friendly medium.

subgenres.name: Eurodance
subgenres.description: Takes elements of Euro-Disco, House, Techno, and Hi-NRG while featuring on-beat kick, hi-hat and snare sounds at around 110 to 150 bpm.

subgenres.name: Bubblegum Dance
subgenres.description: Playful, childlike style with a Bubblegum-like atmosphere that often incorporates high-pitched, light-hearted, and usually female-fronted vocals.

subgenres.name: Italo Dance
subgenres.description: Appeared in the 1990s after the decline of Italo-Disco, featuring rhythmic influence from that genre.

subgenres.name: Footwork
subgenres.description: Extensive use of drum fills, tom drums, handclaps, and snares within fast-paced, highly syncopated beats not bound to a 4/4 kick rhythm.

subgenres.name: Footwork Jungle
subgenres.description: Combining Footwork's archetypal percussion, skittering drum fills, handclaps, and syncopated rhythms, with Drum and Bass drum programming and breakbeats, merging the two into unconventional, frantic drumming and dense, off-kilter rhythms.

subgenres.name: Glitch Hop
subgenres.description: Tempos around 100-110 BPM, swung, bouncy drum patterns, and a focus on upbeat, danceable drops and buildups.

subgenres.name: Ghetto Funk
subgenres.description: Rich sampling, drawing from classic Hip Hop as well as from Funk and Soul, and strong midtempo break grooves.

subgenres.name: Neurohop
subgenres.description: Features the complex bass of Neurofunk and a frantic and mechanical sound design.

subgenres.name: Grime
subgenres.description: UK Garage-derived production style characterized by dark, fast-paced, often aggressive beats that commonly features fast-paced MCing.

subgenres.name: Neo-Grime
subgenres.description: Mixes Wave with Grime and other forms of UK Electronic music.

subgenres.name: Weightless
subgenres.description: Typically instrumental, leftfield Grime style characterized by sparse, 'weightless' percussion and spectral, atmospheric production.

subgenres.name: Hardcore
subgenres.description: Umbrella term for a wide variety of extremely fast-paced, energetic Electronic Dance Music styles that have been developed since the early 1990s.

subgenres.name: Acidcore
subgenres.description: Developed out of the 1990s Acid Techno scene utilizing its prominence of 'acid' TB-303 bassline sequences into more intense rhythms derived from earlier Hardcore [EDM], Gabber and Trance music.

subgenres.name: Belgian Techno
subgenres.description: Early form of Hardcore [EDM], resulting from the further evolution of New Beat due to the strong influence of Techno and EBM.

subgenres.name: Breakbeat Hardcore
subgenres.description: Originated from the combination of sampled breakbeats and energetic rhythms with the 'rave' influences set by early-1990s Techno and Acid House, including upbeat 'stab' riffing and sample-based production.

subgenres.name: Breakcore
subgenres.description: Mixes Hardcore [EDM] with cut-up, complex, and frequently noisy breakbeats at very high tempos inspired by Jungle and Drum and Bass, often with heavy use of sampling.

subgenres.name: Crossbreed
subgenres.description: Harsh and dense mixture of Darkstep with Hardcore [EDM] developed in the late 2000s.

subgenres.name: Darkcore
subgenres.description: Aggressive, dark, and often midtempo with influences from Doomcore, Industrial Hardcore, and Nu Style Gabber.

subgenres.name: Deathchant Hardcore
subgenres.description: Took shape in the UK in the late 1990s and early 2000s, characterized by rapid rhythms with Gabber-influenced kicks, frequent use of breakbeats and Hip Hop-inspired sampling.

subgenres.name: Digital Hardcore
subgenres.description: High-tempo fusion of Hardcore Punk and Electronic, combining harsh vocals and electric guitars of the former with electronic instruments.

subgenres.name: Doomcore
subgenres.description: Often somber and contemplative in mood, a feature achieved by the common use of long-stretched ambient pads, and sometimes even samples of screaming and other 'spooky' sounds.

subgenres.name: Freeform Hardcore
subgenres.description: Emerged in the mid-1990s, combining fast and hard-hitting rhythms with heavy influence from the synthesizers of Trance.

subgenres.name: Frenchcore
subgenres.description: Off-beat, bouncy rhythmic patterns and tempos around the 200 BPM range.

subgenres.name: Gabber
subgenres.description: Fast-paced and energetic, often in the 160-220 BPM range, with a hallmark of a distinctive distorted kick sound.

subgenres.name: Happy Hardcore
subgenres.description: Emerged in the 1990s from the UK Breakbeat Hardcore scene; characterized by saccharine vocals, uplifting piano riffs and spacey effects, gradually developing to emphasize extremely fast-paced four-on-the-floor beats.

subgenres.name: Hardtek
subgenres.description: Modern hard dance-influenced version of the 'tribecore' sound featuring deep alternating basses and festival EDM-influenced drops.

subgenres.name: Industrial Hardcore
subgenres.description: Fuses the sonic palettes and aesthetics of Industrial & Noise with the intense rhythms of Gabber, Speedcore, Doomcore and other subsequent styles.

subgenres.name: J-core
subgenres.description: More energetic and eclectic form of Japanese Hardcore [EDM].

subgenres.name: Speedcore
subgenres.description: Exceedingly fast tempos, frequently above 300 BPM, and often aggressive themes and samples.

subgenres.name: Terrorcore
subgenres.description: Utilizes rhythms from earlier Gabber with a faster BPM (usually no more than 300) and darker approach.

subgenres.name: Uptempo Hardcore
subgenres.description: Utilizes lo-fi production, harsh kicks, and elements borrowed from Rawstyle and other gritty Hardcore [EDM] styles while usually sitting at around 185-220 BPM.

subgenres.name: Hard Dance
subgenres.description: Umbrella term for EDM mainly developed out of Hard Trance and UK Hard House; usually characterized by fast tempos, hard kick drums and a 'bouncy' syncopated groove.

subgenres.name: Hardstyle
subgenres.description: Hard, four-on-the-floor kick drums, fast tempo around 150 BPM, reverse bass and harsh, distorted synths.

subgenres.name: Hardtek
subgenres.description: Modern hard dance-influenced version of the 'tribecore' sound featuring deep alternating basses and festival EDM-influenced drops.

subgenres.name: Hard Trance
subgenres.description: Rave-oriented form of Trance infusing its atmospheres with faster, thumping rhythms and strong melodic / bassline sections, initially spawning out of the first wave in early-1990s Western Europe.

subgenres.name: Jumpstyle
subgenres.description: Features a heavy 909 kick drum, four-on-the-floor beat, and a tempo between 140 and 150 BPM.

subgenres.name: Lento violento
subgenres.description: Features a 'slow and violent' sound between 70-120 BPM with hard kicks inspired by Hardcore [EDM] and Hardstyle.

subgenres.name: NRG
subgenres.description: Derived from UK Hard House; featuring darker, more anthemic Trance beats and a tempo of 155-165 BPM.

subgenres.name: UK Hardcore
subgenres.description: Four-on-the-floor beat around 175 BPM, thick, prominent basslines, and uplifting synth leads, with a cleaner and more accessible sound than other forms of Hardcore [EDM].

subgenres.name: UK Hard House
subgenres.description: Defined by offbeat bass patterns, compressed 909-style drums, buildup-drop structures, hoover sounds, and tempos between 120 and 155 BPM.

subgenres.name: Hard Drum
subgenres.description: Highly percussive, syncopated rhythms, influences from global contemporary genres, and lack of melodic elements, with a tempo lingering between 130 BPM.

subgenres.name: Hardvapour
subgenres.description: Influenced by Hardcore [EDM] and Techno and made in response to the Vaporwave movement.

subgenres.name: Hardwave
subgenres.description: Harder, festival-oriented offshoot of Wave, combining its 'reese' basses and icy synths with Trap [EDM] drum patterns, build-up-drop structures, and fuller sound influenced by Trance and Hardstyle.

subgenres.name: Hardstyle
subgenres.description: A genre characterized by its hard four-on-the-floor beats, aggressive synths, and up to 150 BPM.

subgenres.name: Dubstyle
subgenres.description: Characterized by the incorporation of the half-time rhythms and wobbly basslines of Dubstep.

subgenres.name: Euphoric Hardstyle
subgenres.description: Melodic, more lighthearted, and accessible Hardstyle.

subgenres.name: Psystyle
subgenres.description: Prominent Psytrance influences, especially the basslines and energy of mainstream psytrance.

subgenres.name: Rawstyle
subgenres.description: Incorporates earlier Hardstyle and Hardcore [EDM] influences into the sound of 2010s hardstyle, creating a distinctly harsh, simplistic, raw, and dark sound, with fast BPM.

subgenres.name: House
subgenres.description: A genre of Electronic Dance Music characterized by a repetitive four on the floor beat and a tempo of 120 to 130 beats per minute.

subgenres.name: Acid House
subgenres.description: Emerged in the mid-1980s, characterized by repetitive basslines created with the distinctive modulated 'squelching' sound of the Roland TB-303 synthesizer.

subgenres.name: Afro House
subgenres.description: Emerged by fusing Deep House with Southern African Music, characterized by hypnotizing drum patterns of shakers and congas, often sampled African vocals or soulful original features, and spiritual, organic, melodic atmosphere.

subgenres.name: Amapiano
subgenres.description: House from South Africa deriving from previous popular genres including Gqom, Kwaito, and Deep House.

subgenres.name: Ambient House
subgenres.description: Primarily British genre developed in the 1990s with beats, synthesizers, and vocals in styles similar to House, treated with effects that are often described as 'dream-like' or 'chilled out'.

subgenres.name: Bass House
subgenres.description: Busy, punchy percussion, prominent basslines and dirty, distorted synths resembling other bass music genres, with influences including Brostep, Fidget House, Bassline, Speed Garage, and Tech House.

subgenres.name: Big Room House
subgenres.description: Energetic, festival-oriented style characterized by heavy reverb, intense build-ups, strong kicks, minimalistic drop melodies, and sparse, raw breakdowns.

subgenres.name: Bubbling House
subgenres.description: Developed in the Netherlands in the 2000s, combining the older style of Bubbling with more modern House, especially Dutch House.

subgenres.name: Changa tuki
subgenres.description: Emerged in Caracas; highly influenced by 1990s Techno and Tribal House, featuring fast tempos, strident synthesizers, hard-thumping percussion lines, and plenty of breakbeats.

subgenres.name: Chicago Hard House
subgenres.description: Originated from Chicago around the mid-1990s as a development of Ghetto House, emphasizing hard-hitting, off-beat drum patterns, fast tempos, and lack of melodies.

subgenres.name: Chicago House
subgenres.description: Umbrella term for a broad variety of House that originated from Chicago in the (mostly mid-to-late) 1980s and early 90s.

subgenres.name: Deep House
subgenres.description: Emerged in the United States during the mid-1980s, featuring a relaxed tempo and influences from Jazz, Funk, and Soul.

subgenres.name: Diva House
subgenres.description: Dominant, anthemic female vocals, common use of piano stabs, and energetic, driving four-on-the-floor rhythms.

subgenres.name: Electro House
subgenres.description: Warm analog basslines, punchy percussion, crisp high-pitched synthesizer leads, and clipped vocal samples.

subgenres.name: Dutch House
subgenres.description: High-pitched wonky synth melodies and heavy influence from Fidget House which developed in the Netherlands around 2007-08.

subgenres.name: Fidget House
subgenres.description: Makes heavy use of Breakbeat Hardcore-esque synth stabs, pitch bending of basslines, and cut-up vocal samples, as well as glitchy, or 'choppy', 4/4 rhythms.

subgenres.name: Euro House
subgenres.description: Vocal-focused style emerging in the late 1980s in Europe, developing in parallel with Eurodance.

subgenres.name: French House
subgenres.description: Originated in France in the mid-1990s, characterized by the use of filtered (low-pass, phaser, etc.) samples of Funk and Disco.

subgenres.name: Funky House
subgenres.description: Funky, warm, catchy basslines on top of looped Funk or Disco samples, resulting in an upbeat, bouncy, and pacy groove.

subgenres.name: Future Funk
subgenres.description: Sample-based form of House which formed out of Vaporwave in the early 2010s.

subgenres.name: Future House
subgenres.description: Features distinctive metallic-sounding drops and frequency-modulated basslines at around 120-130 BPM.

subgenres.name: Garage House
subgenres.description: Disco-influenced style of House that developed in the 1980s, incorporating elements of Gospel, Soul, and Dub, before evolving into a more upbeat style that prominently features crisp syncopated hi-hats and synth stabs.

subgenres.name: Ghetto House
subgenres.description: Rough sound based around minimal drum machine-driven tracks and heavy usage of vocal samples.

subgenres.name: G-House
subgenres.description: Deep, dark form of House music that primarily incorporates rap samples or original rapping on top of minimal, bassy beats.

subgenres.name: Gqom
subgenres.description: Evolved from South African House, specifically Kwaito; often described as a more minimal and raw version.

subgenres.name: Hip House
subgenres.description: Incorporates production elements of early Hip Hop and usually rapping into 1980s House.

subgenres.name: Italo House
subgenres.description: Originated in Italy during the late 1980s, making use of anthemic pianos, diva vocals, and Dance-Pop song structures.

subgenres.name: Jackin' House
subgenres.description: Punchy, 'shuffly' percussion, strong grooves, funky basslines, and chopped-up samples.

subgenres.name: Latin House
subgenres.description: Emerged in the second half of the 1980s, blending four-on-the-floor beats with Hispanic American Music influences from Puerto Rico, Mexico, Cuba, Dominica, and Colombia.

subgenres.name: Melodic House
subgenres.description: Arpeggiated synth lines, focus on a chilled and laid-back atmosphere, and influence from genres such as Progressive House and Deep House.

subgenres.name: Microhouse
subgenres.description: Stripped-down, minimal form of House, originating in the late 90s, which takes influence from Minimal Techno, Glitch and IDM.

subgenres.name: Organic House
subgenres.description: Subtle drums and grooves, slow tempos, and acoustic, traditional instrumentation, resulting in an organic, warm sound and spiritual atmosphere.

subgenres.name: Outsider House
subgenres.description: Mostly derived from Deep House; intentional use of rough, lo-fi production, often utilizing a mix of analog/analog-like and digital instrumentation.

subgenres.name: Phonk House
subgenres.description: Merges Drift Phonk's nocturnal atmospheres, cowbell melodies, vocal samples, and energetic production, with House rhythms and tempos, characterized by a banging and upbeat sound.

subgenres.name: Progressive House
subgenres.description: Trance-influenced strain of House that grew to prominence in the early 1990s, using polished production and gradual progressions.

subgenres.name: Romanian Popcorn
subgenres.description: Emerged in the second half of the 2000s in Romania, often featuring brass melodies and 'staccato' pluck grooves.

subgenres.name: Speed Garage
subgenres.description: Primarily British style that paved the way for UK Garage, combining cut-up vocal samples and sped up four-on-the-floor Garage House rhythms with Jungle-esque basslines.

subgenres.name: Tech House
subgenres.description: Emerged in the mid-1990s taking influences from Techno, broadly characterized by minimalistic and repetitive melodies, focus on the bassline, and constant groove recognizable by prominent off-beat hi-hats.

subgenres.name: Tribal House
subgenres.description: Prominent, syncopated rhythms of tribal drums such as toms and bongos on top of a House beat, usually resulting in a percussive, energetic sound, while ranging in mood.

subgenres.name: Tropical House
subgenres.description: Offshoot of Deep House featuring slow tempos around 100-115 BPM, light percussion and acoustic instrumentation, setting out to create a relaxed, summery, beach-like atmosphere.

subgenres.name: UK Hard House
subgenres.description: Defined by offbeat bass patterns, compressed 909-style drums, buildup-drop structures, hoover sounds, and tempos between 120 and 155 BPM.

subgenres.name: Vinahouse
subgenres.description: Fast-paced House popular in Vietnam, remixing Vietnamese melodies.

subgenres.name: Techno
subgenres.description: A genre of Electronic Dance Music that emerged in Detroit, MI, in the United States during the mid-to-late 1980s.

subgenres.name: Ambient Techno
subgenres.description: Blends the mechanical, repetitive beats of Techno with atmospheres and textures inspired by Ambient music, resulting in slower tempos and more understated rhythms.

subgenres.name: Belgian Techno
subgenres.description: Early form of Hardcore [EDM], resulting from the further evolution of New Beat due to the strong influence of Techno and EBM.

subgenres.name: Bleep Techno
subgenres.description: Established in the late 1980s in the breakdancing and early rave scene of Yorkshire in the North of England, notable for its 'bleepy' synth lines and heavy sub-bass.

subgenres.name: Detroit Techno
subgenres.description: Features a signature mechanical, detached sound that echoed the atmosphere of Detroit's nightlife and incorporated influences from Electro, Chicago House, as well as Synthpop and Electro-Disco.

subgenres.name: Freetekno
subgenres.description: Originated in the early 1990s, commonly played at free parties in Europe, and features a repetitive pounding kick drum at tempos of 170 BPM or above.

subgenres.name: Hardgroove Techno
subgenres.description: Popular in the early 2000s; features layered shuffling percussion.

subgenres.name: Hard Techno
subgenres.description: Typically rave-oriented form characterized by hard, prominent kick drums, pounding rhythms, fast tempos around 140-160 BPM, and aggressive, often distorted sounds.

subgenres.name: Industrial Techno
subgenres.description: Harder, darker style of Techno which draws parallels with factories and the rhythm of machinery.

subgenres.name: Melodic Techno
subgenres.description: Trance-influenced subgenre that was established in the mid-to-late 2010s, characterized by gradually progressing structure, and hypnotizing, atmospheric sound with arpeggiated, minor melodies, playing at around 120-125 BPM.

subgenres.name: Minimal Techno
subgenres.description: Stripped-down and sparse, often featuring a dark sound and a slow, steady development through the track.

subgenres.name: Dub Techno
subgenres.description: Fuses elements of Minimal Techno with characteristics of Dub.

subgenres.name: Peak Time Techno
subgenres.description: Hard, dynamic, energetic and accessible subgenre featuring strong kicks, massive dirty synths, tempos around 130 BPM, more suspenseful structures with breaks and build-ups, and big, modern, festival-oriented sound; rose to high popularity in the late 2010s.

subgenres.name: Wonky Techno
subgenres.description: Strays from the standard beat of Techno, opting for a more fractured sound.

subgenres.name: Trance
subgenres.description: A genre of Electronic Dance Music that developed in the early 1990s, characterized by a tempo lying between 125 and 150 bpm (beats per minute), repeating melodic phrases, and a musical form that builds up and down throughout a track.

subgenres.name: Acid Trance
subgenres.description: Incorporates 'squelching' acid basslines into Trance's evolving structure.

subgenres.name: Big Room Trance
subgenres.description: Incorporates production features associated with Big Room House and dirty, distorted leads influenced by Electro House, Dutch House and Hardstyle.

subgenres.name: Dream Trance
subgenres.description: Slow tempo (about 130 BPM) with strong roots in Progressive House, using beats typical of Eurodance and Dance-Pop; emphasizes a laid-back, carefree, and dreamlike sound.

subgenres.name: Euro-Trance
subgenres.description: More accessible, usually vocal-driven subgenre that emerged as a fusion with Eurodance, featuring its catchy, upbeat melodies and offbeat basslines while keeping the fast tempos.

subgenres.name: Hard Trance
subgenres.description: Rave-oriented form of Trance infusing its atmospheres with faster, thumping rhythms and strong melodic / bassline sections, initially spawning out of the first wave in early-1990s Western Europe.

subgenres.name: Ibiza Trance
subgenres.description: Builds on the relaxing island atmosphere of Balearic Beat, though with a slightly faster tempo of around 130 BPM.

subgenres.name: NRG
subgenres.description: Derived from UK Hard House; featuring darker, more anthemic Trance beats and a tempo of 155-165 BPM.

subgenres.name: Progressive Trance
subgenres.description: Combination of Trance and Progressive House which emerged in Western Europe in the early to mid-1990s.

subgenres.name: Psytrance
subgenres.description: Trance with a psychedelic feel and energetic sound, based around influences from Goa Trance and Acid Trance.

subgenres.name: Tech Trance
subgenres.description: Late 1990s-emerging subgenre characterized by energetic percussion with loud kicks, filtered hi-hats and tribal drums; side-chained, detuned and repetitive leads, as well as other raw, distorted, and complex sounds influenced by Techno, Hard Trance and Electro House.

subgenres.name: Uplifting Trance
subgenres.description: Euphoric melodies, buildup-breakdown-anthem structures, common usage of supersaws, and a BPM range of usually around 135-142.

subgenres.name: Vocal Trance
subgenres.description: Melodic, polished, Pop-like, and vocal-focused with around 120-145 BPM and frequent overlap with Progressive Trance, Uplifting Trance, and Euro-Trance.

subgenres.name: Trap
subgenres.description: A subgenre of Hip Hop music that originated in the Southern United States during the early 1990s.

subgenres.name: Festival Trap
subgenres.description: Massive, sub-bass-heavy drops with simple melodies, synth leads and production influenced by Big Room House; highly popular from 2013 to 2015.

subgenres.name: Hard Trap
subgenres.description: Often abrasive subgenre of Trap [EDM] with heavy influence from Hardstyle.

subgenres.name: Heaven Trap
subgenres.description: Blends Trap [EDM]’s signature percussion and sub-basses with euphoric, uplifting, melodious drops prominently derived from Festival Progressive House, contrary to the gritty, 'dirty' nature of other EDM trap styles.

subgenres.name: Hybrid Trap
subgenres.description: Blending Trap [EDM]'s typical percussion and sub-basses with major influences from heavy bass music genres, and in particular, metallic, gritty, and off-kilter sound design, originally derived from Brostep.

subgenres.name: Twerk
subgenres.description: Fast-paced; draws influence from Bounce and Miami Bass.

subgenres.name: UK Garage
subgenres.description: A genre of electronic music originating from England in the early 1990s, combining elements of House, Dance-pop, and R&B.

subgenres.name: 2-Step
subgenres.description: Originating in London and popular in the late 1990s; jittery, shuffling rhythms rarely following a four-on-the-floor pattern.

subgenres.name: Bassline
subgenres.description: Strong emphasis on intricate basslines as well as four-on-the-floor beat patterns.

subgenres.name: Breakstep
subgenres.description: Differentiated from other UK Garage subgenres by its use of hard-hitting Breakbeat rhythms, as well as its focus on heavy, rolling basslines.

subgenres.name: Future Garage
subgenres.description: Derivative of UK Garage combining influences from the rhythms of late 1990s and early 2000s 2-Step with novel moods and production approaches, commonly featuring jittery, broken rhythms, vocal chops, and warm synth pads and plucks.

subgenres.name: Speed Garage
subgenres.description: Primarily British style that paved the way for UK Garage, combining cut-up vocal samples and sped up four-on-the-floor Garage House rhythms with Jungle-esque basslines.

subgenres.name: Miami Bass
subgenres.description: Sustained Roland TR-808 kick drums and faster tempos, along with a distinct Electro influence.

description: Uses non-traditional electronic instrumentation and sound manipulation technology as the primary backbone of a composition.

subgenres.name: Bit Music
subgenres.description: Created by sound chips, cards, and sequencers found in video game consoles, personal computers, and arcade machines, as well as synthesizers emulating these sounds.

subgenres.name: Chiptune
subgenres.description: Used primarily in the 1980s within the context of 8-bit Video Game Music, combining simple synthesized waveforms and noise in a compositionally limited but overtly melodic style.

subgenres.name: FM Synthesis
subgenres.description: Sound synthesis that combines the simple waveforms of Chiptune with modulating oscillators to create a bouncier synthesizer sound that would be used in arcade cabinets and home video game consoles like the Sega Mega Drive/Genesis in the late 1980s.

subgenres.name: MIDI Music
subgenres.description: Intended for real-time sequenced playback via MIDI protocol on MIDI devices and used primarily in 1990s PC Video Game Music, arranger keyboards and karaoke.

subgenres.name: Sequencer & Tracker
subgenres.description: Composed for early home computer and game consoles from the late 1980s to the late 1990s, primarily for video game soundtracks.

subgenres.name: Chillout
subgenres.description: Broad category of many relaxed styles of Electronic music which predominantly draw influence from Electronic Dance Music subgenres and Ambient.

subgenres.name: Ambient Dub
subgenres.description: Takes cues from Ambient and Dub reggae, featuring the atmosphere of the former and the Jamaican-style basslines, percussion, and psychedelic production techniques of the latter.

subgenres.name: Ambient House
subgenres.description: Primarily British genre developed in the 1990s with beats, synthesizers, and vocals in styles similar to House, treated with effects that are often described as 'dream-like' or 'chilled out'.

subgenres.name: Ambient Trance
subgenres.description: Emerged in the mid-1990s mainly in the form of Chillout remixes of Trance tracks; incorporates its arpeggiated synthesizer sound into Downtempo and Ambient contexts.

subgenres.name: Balearic Beat
subgenres.description: Variety of relaxed, laid-back music that originates from the Balearic Islands off the coast of Spain, and particularly the club scene in Ibiza.

subgenres.name: Barber Beats
subgenres.description: Borrows elements from Downtempo, Trip Hop, and Instrumental Hip Hop; emulates 1990s and 2000s Chillout music.

subgenres.name: Downtempo
subgenres.description: Atmospheric and groove-based with relaxed tempos and mellow beats.

subgenres.name: Psybient
subgenres.description: Heavy influence from Psytrance and Goa Trance incorporated in an atmospheric Ambient context.

subgenres.name: Trip Hop
subgenres.description: Evokes a surreal, trippy, dreamy, and sometimes dark atmosphere with offbeat turntable scratches, light vocal melodies, and Hip Hop-influenced beats.

subgenres.name: Dungeon Synth
subgenres.description: Focuses on evoking epic and atmospheric soundscapes commonly associated with fantasy and medieval settings through the usage of synthesizers, keyboards, and drum machines.

subgenres.name: Comfy Synth
subgenres.description: Calm, peaceful and soothing sounds, as well as nostalgic, sentimental, or childish atmospheres and aesthetics; often incorporates wholesome themes while utilizing lo-fi or hazy recordings and influences from New Age.

subgenres.name: Winter Synth
subgenres.description: Cold, minimalistic, and repetitive soundscapes, commonly invoking imagery of winter.

subgenres.name: Electroacoustic
subgenres.description: Manipulation and processing of sound sources to create atmospheric pieces.

subgenres.name: Acousmatic Music
subgenres.description: Fixed-media Electroacoustic music designed to be reproduced by multiple loudspeakers without the presence of instrumentalists and visual cues.

subgenres.name: EAI
subgenres.description: Slow paced, physical, textured aesthetic - often created using unconventional instruments processed through a computer.

subgenres.name: Musique concrète
subgenres.description: Manipulation of recorded sounds, mostly Field Recordings, natural sounds, and real-world noises, as a process of abstracting 'concrete' sounds, or 'sound objects', from their acoustic origins.

subgenres.name: Electro-Industrial
subgenres.description: Formed in the late 1980s and early 1990s; grew out of a combination of EBM and Industrial.

subgenres.name: Dark Electro
subgenres.description: Emerged in the early 1990s in Europe, combining EBM beats with the abrasiveness of old school Industrial but with a greater focus on a horror-inspired atmosphere and harsh, distorted vocals.

subgenres.name: Aggrotech
subgenres.description: Based on the dark atmosphere of Dark Electro, typically characterized by more aggressive Hardcore [EDM]-influenced beats and harsh/distorted vocals.

subgenres.name: Indietronica
subgenres.description: Leftfield or DIY approach characterised by simpler Pop-informed melodies, often incorporating vocals or live instrumentation alongside Electronic production.

subgenres.name: Chillwave
subgenres.description: Emulates vintage aesthetics and popular musical styles of the 1980s/1990s altered by modern recording technology to create a hazy dreamlike atmosphere.

subgenres.name: Chillsynth
subgenres.description: Mixes Synthwave with major Chillwave elements, characterized by a dreamy and relaxed sound.

subgenres.name: Glitch Pop
subgenres.description: Incorporates elements of more experimental Electronic styles like IDM and Glitch.

subgenres.name: Picopop
subgenres.description: Originated in the early 2000s as an offshoot of the Japanese Shibuya-kei movement when artists introduced more prominent 'bleepy' electronic elements and faster tempos.

subgenres.name: Latin Electronic
subgenres.description: Combines Electronic with Latin American influences; started at the end of the 1990s.

subgenres.name: Changa tuki
subgenres.description: Emerged in Caracas; highly influenced by 1990s Techno and Tribal House, featuring fast tempos, strident synthesizers, hard-thumping percussion lines, and plenty of breakbeats.

subgenres.name: Digital Cumbia
subgenres.description: Mixes an Electronic sound into traditional Cumbia through influences from House, Dancehall, Hyphy, and Dubstep.

subgenres.name: Electro latino
subgenres.description: Mixes elements of Merengue and Reggaetón with polished production from mainstream House subgenres; often shares traits with Latin Pop, having anthemic melodies and verse-chorus structures.

subgenres.name: Electrotango
subgenres.description: Combines Tango rhythms and melodies with Electronic music.

subgenres.name: Nortec
subgenres.description: Samples and synthesizes Mexican styles like Banda sinaloense and Norteño into a sound related to IDM and House.

subgenres.name: Tribal Guarachero
subgenres.description: Features percussion from Cumbia and Mexican Folk Music with upbeat Electro House-derived production and fast, triplet-oriented rhythmic patterns.

subgenres.name: Minimal Wave
subgenres.description: Retrospective term for more Electronic and minimal forms of New Wave, Post-Punk, Synthpop, and related styles, tending towards a more sparse and lo-fi sound.

subgenres.name: Minimal Synth
subgenres.description: Minimal and distinctly DIY take on Synthpop with a bleak and naive aesthetic.

subgenres.name: Power Electronics
subgenres.description: Waves of feedback, screeching analog synthesizers, and harsh, screamed vocals.

subgenres.name: Death Industrial
subgenres.description: Combines the abrasive textures of Noise and Industrial music with dark, brooding drones and atmospheres.

subgenres.name: Progressive Electronic
subgenres.description: Synthesizer-driven genre focusing on developing, often longform compositions and drawing inspiration from various sources such as Progressive Rock, Western Classical Music, and Ambient.

subgenres.name: Berlin School
subgenres.description: Atmospheric, multi-layered synthesizer textures; pioneered in Berlin in the 1970s as an offshoot to the Krautrock movement.

subgenres.name: Synth Pop
subgenres.description: Led by a prominent, melodic synthesizer sound, often with reverberated drum machine patterns that create a distinct atmospheric feel commonly associated with the 1980s.

subgenres.name: Futurepop
subgenres.description: Derivative of EBM, retaining its apocalyptic worldview but incorporating heavy influence from the melodic style of Synthpop.

subgenres.name: Pon-chak disco
subgenres.description: Heavily influenced by Electro-Disco, featuring cheap 'electronic organ' synth leads and minimalistic, repetitive rhythms.

subgenres.name: Techno kayō
subgenres.description: Offshoot of 1980s Kayōkyoku and Idol kayō incorporating characteristics from Synthpop.

subgenres.name: Synthwave
subgenres.description: Rooted in 1980s synth music, characterized by large, throbbing 'retro' synths and visual elements, often features upbeat percussion and/or epic, cinematic atmospheres.

subgenres.name: Chillsynth
subgenres.description: Mixes Synthwave with major Chillwave elements, characterized by a dreamy and relaxed sound.

subgenres.name: Darksynth
subgenres.description: Incorporates atmospheric Horror Synth and faster tempos into a much heavier and darker sound.

subgenres.name: Vapor
subgenres.description: Meta-genre beginning with the rise of Vaporwave and the aesthetics that it spawned.

subgenres.name: Chillsynth
subgenres.description: Mixes Synthwave with major Chillwave elements, characterized by a dreamy and relaxed sound.

subgenres.name: Darksynth
subgenres.description: Incorporates atmospheric Horror Synth and faster tempos into a much heavier and darker sound.

subgenres.name: Broken Transmission
subgenres.description: Uses samples taken from TV broadcasts, advertising, film, radio, and other sources - often slowing down and manipulating the sound heavily.

subgenres.name: Eccojams
subgenres.description: Simple, prototypical Vaporwave style, heavily influenced by Chopped and Screwed and Glitch, that features short, slowed-down, lyric-focused, sampled loops smothered in reverb and continuously repeated, usually taken from late 20th century music.

subgenres.name: Mallsoft
subgenres.description: Blends the main characteristics of Vaporwave with what can be described as background/elevator music.

subgenres.name: Slushwave
subgenres.description: Specializes in a distinct form of sample manipulation rooted in Vaporwave, heavily utilizing multi-layered effects to create a specific 'slushy', hypnagogic sound usually sequenced in soft, repetitive Ambient-based soundscapes.

subgenres.name: Wave
subgenres.description: Melancholic, atmospheric, melodic beats, defined by its Trap and Cloud Rap influence, ethereal and cold production style, and abundant use of sub bass.

subgenres.name: Hardwave
subgenres.description: Harder, festival-oriented offshoot of Wave, combining its 'reese' basses and icy synths with Trap [EDM] drum patterns, build-up-drop structures, and fuller sound influenced by Trance and Hardstyle.

subgenres.name: Neo-Grime
subgenres.description: Mixes Wave with Grime and other forms of UK Electronic music.

description: Most radical approaches throughout history, featuring non-traditional production methods resulting in sounds and styles that go largely beyond traditional boundaries.

Conducted Improvisation.description: Collective improvisation directed by a conductor.

Data Sonification.description: Usage of data to create sound, soundscapes and music mostly as a way to illustrate its information.

Drone.description: Characterized by a focus on long, sustained tones and tone clusters, or repetition of single notes.

Electroacoustic.description: Manipulation and processing of sound sources to create atmospheric pieces.

Acousmatic Music.description: Fixed-media Electroacoustic music designed to be reproduced by multiple loudspeakers without the presence of instrumentalists and visual cues.

EAI.description: Slow paced, physical, textured aesthetic - often created using unconventional instruments processed through a computer.

Musique concr\u00e8te.description: Manipulation of recorded sounds, mostly Field Recordings, natural sounds, and real-world noises, as a process of abstracting 'concrete' sounds, or 'sound objects', from their acoustic origins.

Free Improvisation.description: Improvised music which, in descending from Free Jazz and classical Indeterminacy, further abandons the prescriptions of harmonic or rhythmic structures which characterized those genres.

EAI.description: Slow paced, physical, textured aesthetic - often created using unconventional instruments processed through a computer.

Futurism.description: Radical and militant attitude, rejection of Western Classical Music and traditional criteria of craft, non-conformity, and a fascination with machines.

Glitch.description: Uses abstract sound design and malfunctioning electronics—CD skips, data corruption, and hardware noise—as main compositional elements.

Indeterminacy.description: Leaves elements of composition, performance, or both up to chance.

Industrial.description: Emerged out of Punk and avant-garde art movements in the mid-1970s, often characterized by a bleak, mechanical atmosphere, the use of metallic percussion as well as other unconventional instruments, and extensive use of sampling influenced by Musique concrète.

Power Electronics.description: Waves of feedback, screeching analog synthesizers, and harsh, screamed vocals.

Death Industrial.description: Combines the abrasive textures of Noise and Industrial music with dark, brooding drones and atmospheres.

Power Noise.description: Combines looped samples of Noise with Electronic rhythms.

Microsound.description: Usage of sounds on an incredibly small scale.

Modern Creative.description: Style of semi-improvisation that derives heavily from both the composition of Modern Classical and the techniques of Avant-Garde Jazz.

Musique concr\u00e8te instrumentale.description: Acoustic, through-composed Classical Music that relies heavily on unconventional instrumental techniques.

Noise.description: Strays away from conventional structure, tonality, and composition and consists predominantly of noise.

Ambient Noise Wall.description: Combines the static approach of Harsh Noise Wall with textures leaning towards Ambient music.

Black Noise.description: Incorporates unconventional sounds with overpowering or constant Noise and Black Metal elements, often being heavily texture-oriented, abrasive, dissonant, atonal, or repetitive.

Gorenoise.description: Combines and subverts Goregrind and Grindcore with brash Noise and even faster drum tempos.

Harsh Noise.description: Highly aggressive walls of sound that assault the listener.

Harsh Noise Wall.description: Harsh, distorted walls of sound that feature few dynamic variations and often take the form of long compositions with little to no change or progression over time.

Plunderphonics.Description: Compositional technique of utilizing and manipulating one or more recognizable recordings to create a new composition.

Reductionism.Description: Experimental music that centers around quiet dynamics and use of silence.

Lowercase.Description: Uses very quiet sounds, often using silence to juxtapose these sounds so as to amplify their intensity.

Onkyo.Description: Exploration of the physical traits of sound rather than music as expression.

Sound Art.Description: Incorporates elements from Experimental music and visual arts, with sound utilized as its primary medium and subject.

Sound Collage.Description: Sound pieces are layered and essentially 'glued' together to create an auditory art piece.

Epic Collage.Description: Defined by its Deconstructed Club sonic palette and its cinematic proportions.

Description: Umbrella encompassing Noise and Industrial, as well as later derivatives that combine the latter aesthetics with other styles and in more accessible directions which fall under Post-Industrial.

Industrial.Description: Emerged out of Punk and avant-garde art movements in the mid-1970s, often characterized by a bleak, mechanical atmosphere, the use of metallic percussion as well as other unconventional instruments, and extensive use of sampling influenced by Musique concrète.

Power Electronics.Description: Waves of feedback, screeching analog synthesizers, and harsh, screamed vocals.

Death Industrial.Description: Combines the abrasive textures of Noise and Industrial music with dark, brooding drones and atmospheres.

Noise.Description: Strays away from conventional structure, tonality, and composition and consists predominantly of noise.

Ambient Noise Wall.Description: Combines the static approach of Harsh Noise Wall with textures leaning towards Ambient music.

Black Noise.Description: Incorporates unconventional sounds with overpowering or constant Noise and Black Metal elements, often being heavily texture-oriented, abrasive, dissonant, atonal, or repetitive.

Gorenoise.Description: Combines and subverts Goregrind and Grindcore with brash Noise and even faster drum tempos.

Harsh Noise.Description: Highly aggressive walls of sound that assault the listener.

Harsh Noise Wall.Description: Harsh, distorted walls of sound that feature few dynamic variations and often take the form of long compositions with little to no change or progression over time.

Power Electronics.Description: Waves of feedback, screeching analog synthesizers, and harsh, screamed vocals.

Death Industrial.Description: Combines the abrasive textures of Noise and Industrial music with dark, brooding drones and atmospheres.

Power Noise.Description: Combines looped samples of Noise with Electronic rhythms.

Post-Industrial.Description: Umbrella group of genres that combine the dark, mechanical aesthetic of early Industrial music with more accessible genres, such as Rock and Electronic Dance Music.

Dark Ambient.Description: Emphasizes an ominous, gloomy, and dissonant atmosphere.

Black Ambient.Description: Incorporates elements such as guitars, synthesizers, harsh or whispered vocals, raw production, or other elements associated with Black Metal and Dungeon Synth.

Ritual Ambient.Description: Dark, deep, disturbing, ritualistic, and occult atmosphere.

Deconstructed Club.Description: Emerged in the 2010s as the hybridization of diverse Electronic Dance Music genres with an abrasive Post-Industrial sound.

EBM.Description: Melodic and beat-driven Electronic Dance Music take on Post-Industrial that developed in the 1980s.

Dark Electro.Description: Emerged in the early 1990s in Europe, combining EBM beats with the abrasiveness of old school Industrial but with a greater focus on a horror-inspired atmosphere and harsh, distorted vocals.

Aggrotech.Description: Based on the dark atmosphere of Dark Electro, typically characterized by more aggressive Hardcore [EDM]-influenced beats and harsh/distorted vocals.

Futurepop.Description: Derivative of EBM, retaining its apocalyptic worldview but incorporating heavy influence from the melodic style of Synthpop.

New Beat.Description: Underground dance music which originated in Belgium around 1987, tending to resemble slower, harder EBM.

Electro-Industrial.Description: Formed in the late 1980s and early 1990s; grew out of a combination of EBM and Industrial.

Epic Collage.Description: Defined by its Deconstructed Club sonic palette and its cinematic proportions.

Industrial Hardcore.Description: Fuses the sonic palettes and aesthetics of Industrial & Noise with the intense rhythms of Gabber, Speedcore, Doomcore and other subsequent styles.

Industrial Hip Hop.Description: Incorporates harsh elements inspired by Industrial music such as blaring, noisy synths, distorted and metallic percussion, as well as more aggressive and off-kilter rapping styles.

Industrial Metal.Description: Incorporates the abrasive and heavy sound from Industrial into a Metal context by using elements from Post-Industrial like synthesizers and drum machines.

Cyber Metal.Description: Originated around 1999, influenced by EBM and Aggrotech with more melodic and less repetitive riffs as well as harsh vocals.

Neue Deutsche H\u00e4rte.Description: Alternative Metal and Industrial Metal that incorporates various aspects of electronic music, specifically Electronic Dance Music.

Industrial Rock.Description: Incorporates abrasive guitars and synthesizers inspired by Industrial and various Post-Industrial styles.

Industrial Techno.Description: Harder, darker style of Techno which draws parallels with factories and the rhythm of machinery.

Birmingham Sound.Description: Cold, mechanical, and hypnotic tracks, typically lacking the harsher and noisier elements of later Industrial Techno.

Martial Industrial.Description: Incorporates elements of traditional European military marches with Neoclassical Darkwave, Dark Ambient, Industrial, and Neofolk.

Power Noise.Description: Combines looped samples of Noise with Electronic rhythms.

Description: Originating in African American communities in the Southern United States around the turn of the 20th century, building on New Orleans Brass Band ensemble and influences from Ragtime and Blues to become a very popular style by the emergence of Swing in the 1930s.

Arabic Jazz.Description: Blending of Arabic Music and Jazz.

Avant-Garde Jazz.Description: Combines traditional or mainstream Jazz stylings with non-traditional techniques of avant-garde art music by experimenting with characteristics such as rhythm, harmony, structure, melody, and instrumentation.

Experimental Big Band.Description: Dispensing with traditional Jazz structures and Swing sounds, instead performing Avant-Garde Jazz and pushing the boundaries of the medium.

Free Jazz.Description: Attempts to break free from the conventions and patterns of earlier Jazz subgenres through the use of elements such as dissonance, atonality, and free-flowing rhythmic structures.

European Free Jazz.Description: Arose in Europe in the late 1960s and early 1970s, moving even further from the Jazz tradition by often dropping the swinging rhythm, taking liberties with the use of atonality and noise.

Yass.Description: Coined in the early 1990s by a group of Polish Avant-Garde Jazz musicians to describe their cross-genre, often arrhythmic, improvised sound.

Bebop.Description: Fast tempos, improvisation, irregular melodic phrasing, and complex harmonies and chord structures.

Big Band.Description: Commonly associated with the golden era of Swing in the 1930s and 1940s, performed by a large ensemble including brass, woodwinds, and usually a rhythm section.

Progressive Big Band.Description: Introduces Western Classical Music compositional techniques into Big Band.

British Dance Band.Description: Came from the dancehalls of the 1920s and 1930s, combining a British take on Jazz with the Music Hall tradition.

Bulawayo Jazz.Description: Emerged from the city of Bulawayo, Zimbabwe in the early 1950s, led by the alto sax and accompanied by ensembles.

Cape Jazz.Description: Developed parallel to American Jazz in the early 20th century, named for its origin in Cape Town, South Africa.

Cartoon Music.Description: Zany and uptempo; incorporated elements of Western Classical Music and Modern Classical into frantic Big Band arrangements, playfully chaotic to match the on-screen actions of cartoon characters and the beat of their movements.

Chamber Jazz.Description: Made by mostly small acoustic-based ensembles with emphasized improvisation and influenced by Neoclassicism and Traditional Folk Music.

Cool Jazz.Description: Developed in the late 1940s alongside and in response to Bebop, featuring a more restrained, emotionally 'cool' style.

Crime Jazz.Description: Gritty, moody style that emerged in the mid-1950s to accompany film noir movies and hard-boiled detective/crime-themed TV shows.

Dark Jazz.Description: Melancholic and gloomy Film noir-inspired atmosphere and influence from Crime Jazz and Dark Ambient.

Dixieland.Description: Developed in New Orleans in the 1910s, incorporating influences from Ragtime and Blues into cacophonous, polyphonic arrangements with instruments trading places between accompaniment and soloist.

ECM Style Jazz.Description: Primarily associated with ECM Records, combining elements of Jazz Fusion with the subdued atmosphere of Cool Jazz and the Western Classical Music bent of Third Stream.

Ethio-Jazz.Description: Unique blend of traditional Ethiopic Music and Jazz.

Flamenco Jazz.Description: Combination of Jazz with Flamenco nuevo, the contemporary style of Flamenco, which was pioneered in the late 1960s.

Hard Bop.Description: A continuation of Bebop that reintroduces more traditional African-American musical features, such as bluesy melodies, slow to medium tempos, and a more groove-oriented sound, while retaining the expressive improvisation.

Indo Jazz.Description: Fuses the various musical traditions of the Indian subcontinent with jazzy musical structures.

Jazz Fusion.Description: Near-universal usage of electric guitars and keyboards coupled with influences from genres such as Rock, Rhythm & Blues, Funk, and Traditional Folk Music, and a relative degree of harmonic simplicity.

Jazz manouche.Description: Combines Jazz with several aspects of Romani Folk Music.

Jazz Poetry.Description: Emerged in the 1920s, incorporating the style and rhythms of Jazz as both art forms spread throughout African-American communities in the United States.

Kr\u00e9yol djaz.Description: Combines Jazz with various styles of French Caribbean Music.

Latin Jazz.Description: Used originally for Afro-Cuban Jazz but, due to its evolution, is now used for the fusion of jazz with Latin American rhythms, especially genres with African origin.

Afro-Cuban Jazz.Description: Combines Jazz with the rhythm of Afro-Cuban music like Habanera.

Marabi.Description: South African Jazz with origins in the 1920s and rooted in traditional South African music.

Kwela.Description: Influenced by Zulu music, characterized by its happy melodies, played by pennywhistle flutes and accompanied by a banjo or a guitar.

Mbaqanga.Description: Emerged from the traditional Marabi Jazz and Swing as well as Kwela popular South African genres.

Modal Jazz.Description: Utilizes musical modes as harmonic framework over traditionally used chord progressions.

Jazz Mugham.Description: Combines Jazz with elements of Azerbaijani Mugham, featuring jazz-inspired instrumental compositions, improvisations, wind and vocal elements, as well as modal scales and ornamentation techniques for emotional depth.

Post-Bop.Description: Grew out of Hard Bop in the early to mid-1960s incorporating certain untraditional elements inspired largely in part from Avant-Garde Jazz, Modal Jazz and eventually, Free Jazz, such as non-diatonic chord progressions, irregular rhythms and amelodic forms.

Samba-jazz.Description: Jazz genre from Brazil that incorporates Samba and/or Bossa nova elements.

Smooth Jazz.Description: Simple melodies and slick production influenced by Pop and R&B.

Soul Jazz.Description: Appeared during the 1950s, when Gospel, Rhythm & Blues and later Soul started to influence the style of prolific jazz musicians.

Spiritual Jazz.Description: Emerged in the 1960s, marked by a mixture of Jazz with approximations of ethnic styles, religious music of non-Christian traditions, and the ecstatic, transcendental aspects of Free Jazz.

Spy Music.Description: Meant to evoke the action and drama of spy films.

Stride.Description: Early form of Ragtime-derived Jazz with improvisational tendencies; named for the performers' left hand 'striding' across the piano keyboard.

Swing.Description: Distinctive rhythm and large backing rhythm section over which solos are performed.

Swing Revival.Description: 1990s alternative take on swing music, incorporating elements from newer genres such as Rockabilly, Ska, and Punk Rock.

Third Stream.Description: A fusion of Jazz and Western Classical Music, with improvisation as a vital component.

Vocal Jazz.Description: Focused on vocals, generally using a more traditional, poppy strong structure and reducing the role of improvisation.
